case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Ajax Products Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1098 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated December 7, 1960, of the Madras High Court in T.C. No. 74 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1098 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated December 7, 1960, of the Madras High Court in T.C. No. 74 of 1959.

facts.text: The respondent-assessee, The Ajax Products Ltd., now under liquidation, was a public limited company incorporated in 1939 to carry on business in the manufacture and sale of steel and abrasives products.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-assessee. The Ajax Products Ltd.-now under liquidation was a public limited companypany incorporated in 1939 to carry on business in the manufacture and sale of steel and abrasives products.

facts.text: On October 30, 1954, the company, at an extraordinary general body meeting, made a resolution to go into voluntary liquidation and the Liquidator appointed by the said resolution carried on the business till the middle of December 1954 when the business was completely closed down.

anchor.surface_text: On October 30, 1954, the companypany, at an extraordinary general body meeting, made a resolution to go into voluntary liquidation and the Liquidator appointed by the said resolution carried on the business till the middle of December 1954 when the business was companypletely closed down.

facts.text: On March 10, 1955, the Liquidator executed a sale deed to Carborundum Universal Limited transferring to the latter the plant, machinery and buildings for a sum of Rs. 10,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: On March 10, 1955, the Liqui- dator executed a sale deed to Garborundum Universal Limited transferring to the latter the plant, machinery and buildings for a sum of Rs. 10,00,000.

facts.text: The said amount was made up of Rs. 1,00,000 being the value of the land, Rs. 1,31,732 being the value of the buildings and Rs. 7,68,268 being the value of plant and machinery.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer treated the sum of Rs. 5,36,034 which was allowed as depreciation in respect of buildings and machinery in the previous years as profits within the meaning of the second proviso to S. 10(2)(vii) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the valuation fixed in the sale deed executed by the assessee in favour of Carborundum Universal Limited was genuine and on that basis, determined the profits liable to tax at a sum of Rs. 3,23,461.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions read 10 1  The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Profits and gains of,, business, profession or vocation in respect of the profit or gains of any business profession or vocation carried on by him.  2  Such profits or gains shall be computed after making the following allowances. in respect of any such building, machinery or plant which has been sold or discarded or demolished or destroyed, the amount by which the written down value thereof exceeds the amount for which the building, machinery or plant, as the case may be, is actually sold or its scrap value Provided Provided further that where the amount for which any such building, machinery or plant is sold,  whether during the continuance of the business or after the cessation thereof,  exceeds the written down value, so-much of the excess as does not exceed the difference between the original cost and the written down value shall be deemed to be profits of the previous year in which the Sale took place

concepts.interpretation: Requires business carried on and assets used during previous year for taxability even post-amendment

anchor.surface_text: The rule of construction of a taxing statute has been pithily stated by Rowlatt J. in Cape Brandy Syndicate v. I.R.C.  1  thus In a Taxing Act one has to look merely at what is clearly said. There is no room for any intendment. There is no equity about a tax. There is no presumption as to a tax. Nothing is to be read in, nothing is to be implied. One can only look fairly at the language used.

concepts.interpretation: Look merely at what is clearly said; no intendment or equity

anchor.surface_text: The proper function of a proviso is that it qualifies the generality of the main enactment by providing an exception and taking out as it were, from the main enactment a portion which, but for the proviso, would fall within the main enactment. Ordinarily, it is foreign to the proper function of a proviso to read it as providing something by way of an addendum or dealing with a subject which is foreign to the main enactment.

concepts.interpretation: Qualifies main section; to be read with principal matter

anchor.surface_text: As the finding of the Tribunal was not based upon any evidence, the High Court was certainly entitled to go behind that finding and answer the question referred to it in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's reasons and estimate based purely on surmises without material on record to support rejection of expert valuation or alternative figure.

holdings.text: By giving the natural meaning to every expression used in the proviso, we reach the result namely that the surplus mentioned in the said proviso is not exigible to tax unless the assessee did business during the accounting year preceding the assessment year and unless such buildings or machinery yielding surplus were used for the business in the said year or at any rate part of the year, though they were sold after the cessation of the business.

anchor.surface_text: By giving the natural meaning to every expression used in the proviso, we reach the result namely that the surplus mentioned in the said proviso is not exigible to tax unless the assessee did business during the accounting year preceding the assessment year and unless such buildings or machinery yielding surplus were used for the business in the said year or at any rate part of the year, though they were sold after the cessation of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural and harmonious construction of proviso with S.10(1); 'such building' limited to those used in business per prior clauses; 'previous year' as defined; illustration of partial year use.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that the amendment only removed one of the conditions for the exigibility of the said surplus to tax namely the cessation of the business and in other respects, the construction put upon the proviso by the earlier decisions of this Court is still good law.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the amendment only removed one of the conditions for the exigibility of the said surplus to tax namely the cessation of the business and in other respects, the construction put upon the proviso by the earlier decisions of this Court is still good law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment adds words allowing post-cessation sales but does not alter requirements of business continuance during previous year and asset usage; follows Pursa Ltd. and Express Newspapers Ltd.; strict construction avoids anomalies.

holdings.text: The result is that the second proviso will only apply to the sale of such machinery which used for the purpose of the business during the accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: The adjective such refers back to clauses (iv), (v), (vi) and (vii) of S. 10(2). Under clause (iv) an allowance is allowed in regard to any premium paid... The result is that the second proviso will only apply to the sale of such machinery which used for the purpose of the business during the accounting year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts authoritative interpretation from Express Newspapers; 'such' refers back to assets qualifying for allowances under clauses (iv)-(vii) i.e., used for business.

precedents.case_name: Liquidators of Pursa Limited v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: surplus made by the company on the sale of plant and machinery could not be brought into charge as profits under the second proviso to s. 10 (2) (vii) of the Act before the amendment as the plant or machinery was not used in the accounting year and sold after cessation of business
precedents.cited_holding: the said surplus was not taxable as the plant or machinery was not used in the accounting year and also for the reason that the said assets were sold in the process of gradual winding up of the company, i.e., after the cessation of the business

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras Express Newspapers, Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v Express Newspapers Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: three conditions for the applicability of the second proviso: 1. During the entire previous year or a part of it the business shall have been carried on by the assessee 2. the machinery shall have been used in the business and 3. the machinery shall have been sold when the business was being carried on and not for the purpose of closing it down or winding it up

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Srinivasan and K. Gapalan. 1 The observations of Mahajan are to the following effect . . . . For purposes of the charging sections of the Act unless otherwise provided for it is

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Srinivasan and K Gopalan
precedents.cited_proposition: For purposes of the charging sections of the Act unless otherwise provided for it is related to a year of assessment immediately following it, but it is not necessarily wedded to an assessment year in all cases and it cannot be said that the expression previous year has no meaning unless it is used in relation to a financial year. In a certain context, it may well mean a completed accounting year immediately preceding the happening of a contingency.

justification_sets.label: Income-tax Act, 1922 S.10(2)(vii) second proviso support

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the amendment only removed one of the conditions for the exigibility of the said surplus to tax namely the cessation of the business and in other respects, the construction put upon the proviso by the earlier decisions of this Court is still good law.

outcome.relief_summary: Amendment to second proviso to S. 10(2)(vii) does not make surplus taxable if no business carried on or assets used in previous year; High Court decision upheld

anchor.surface_text: As the finding of the Tribunal was not based upon any evidence, the High Court was certainly entitled to go behind that finding and answer the question referred to it in the negative.

We therefore hold that the amendment only removed one of the conditions for the exigibility of the said surplus to tax namely the cessation of the business and in other respects, the construction put upon the proviso by the earlier decisions of this Court is still good law.

anchor.surface_text: By giving the natural meaning to every expression used in the proviso, we reach the result namely that the surplus mentioned in the said proviso is not exigible to tax unless the assessee did business during the accounting year preceding the assessment year and unless such buildings or machinery yielding surplus were used for the business in the said year or at any rate part of the year, though they were sold after the cessation of the business.
